abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Carmel's emerald riesling and chenin blanc blend; photo (M)

block.p: AN Israeli hedonist's vision of heaven is Carmel's emerald riesling and chenin blanc blend, lightly cool, alternating with forkfuls of grilled sweet-fleshed St. Peter's fish at a restaurant on the Sea of Galilee.

This tangy, weightless, semidry white, a best-selling starlet at home, enchants Americans but not only Jews. Kosher? Certainly. No less important, the wine expresses hip international technical and aesthetic standards.

AN Israeli hedonist's vision of heaven is Carmel's emerald riesling and chenin blanc blend, lightly cool, alternating with forkfuls of grilled sweet-fleshed St. Peter's fish at a restaurant on the Sea of Galilee.

This tangy, weightless, semidry white, a best-selling starlet at home, enchants Americans but not only Jews. Kosher? Certainly. No less important, the wine expresses hip international technical and aesthetic standards.

Its perfumed confectionery bouquet and spicy tropical-compote flavors, highlighted by a gewurztraminer-like litchi spin and eddies of grapefruit-rind candy, gives the simplest casual dinner party a festive air.

Israel is a homeland for emerald riesling, which is not a true riesling but a marriage, arranged at the University of California at Davis in the 1940's, of German riesling -- the Schiller of European white-wine grapes -- and muscadelle, a supporting actor in Bordeaux.

Baron Edmond de Rothschild founded Carmel in 1882 in Palestine. Jolted by competition, Carmel in recent years has upgraded its farming and cellar to try to recover a long-taken-for-granted Goliath-size market share at home and abroad.

The blend costs $7 at Rye Brook Wine, 259 South Ridge Street, Rye Brook, and $9 at Bronx River Road Discount Liquors, 845 Bronx River Road, in the Fleetwood neighborhood of Yonkers, and Midland Wine and Liquors, 829 Midland Avenue, Yonkers. Eber Bros./Paramount Brands in Port Chester is the distributor.
